text: I call these why-not questions. People ask these why-not questions a lot. So a new thing pops up, and if you're not ready to receive it for some reason, you're not already half there or you don't have a problem that it solves or whatever, it's just threatening and irritating, and you come up with a why-not question.
speaker: Sam Schillace
context: Lenny asks Sam about disruptive innovation and why it's important to him. Sam explains that everything new feels threatening at first, and people react with either acceptance or rejection. He describes how people who aren't ready to receive a new innovation will ask 'why-not' questions - essentially finding reasons why the innovation won't work rather than considering its potential.
text_ko: 저는 이런 걸 '왜 안 되냐는 질문'(why-not questions)이라고 불러요. 사람들은 그런 질문을 정말 자주 해요. 새로운 게 생겼을 때 어떤 이유로 그걸 받아들일 준비가 안 돼 있거나 이미 어느 정도 그쪽으로 와 있지 않거나, 혹은 그걸 해결해 줄 문제가 없다면 그건 위협적이고 짜증나게 느껴져요. 그래서 자연스럽게 왜 안 되냐는 질문이 나오게 되는 거예요.
text_zh: 我管这些叫"为什么不行"的质疑。大家经常会提这种问题。就是说，当有新东西出现的时候，如果你还没准备好接受它，或者你本身就没有遇到这个问题，又或者你觉得自己还没到那个份儿上，那这个新东西对你来说就是个威胁，让人烦躁，然后你就会冒出"为什么不行"这样的质疑。
text_es: A estas las llamo preguntas de "¿y por qué no?". La gente hace mucho este tipo de preguntas. Entonces aparece algo nuevo, y si no estás preparado para recibirlo por alguna razón, o no tienes ya medio camino andado o no tienes un problema que esto resuelva o lo que sea, simplemente lo sientes como una amenaza y te molesta, y ahí es cuando se te ocurre una pregunta de "¿y por qué no?".

text: I think the more interesting ones are the what-if questions, like, what if this does work? Just use your imagination. Think about, how far can I extend the curve? What are the implications of that? I'm an engineer, and engineers are fundamentally pessimistic people.
speaker: Sam Schillace
context: Sam contrasts 'why-not' questions with 'what-if' questions when evaluating new technologies or innovations. He explains that instead of focusing on why something might fail, it's more valuable to imagine what would happen if it succeeds and to think about extending the possibilities. Sam notes that engineers tend to be naturally pessimistic, always looking at problems to solve.
text_ko: 더 흥미로운 건 '만약에' 질문들(what-if questions)인 것 같아요. 예를 들어, 이게 실제로 된다면 어떨까요? 그냥 상상해 보세요. 이 곡선을 얼마나 더 확장할 수 있을까요(extend the curve)? 그게 어떤 의미를 갖게 될까요? 저는 엔지니어고, 엔지니어들은 근본적으로 비관적인 사람들이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得更有意思的是那些假设性的问题，比如说，要是这个真的行得通呢？发挥一下想象力嘛。想想看，这个增长曲线我能推多远？这会带来什么影响？我是工程师出身，我们工程师骨子里都是悲观主义者。
text_es: Creo que las más interesantes son las preguntas de "¿y si...?", como ¿y si esto sí funciona? Solo usa tu imaginación. Piensa en hasta dónde puedes estirar la curva. ¿Cuáles son las implicaciones de eso? Soy ingeniero, y los ingenieros somos básicamente gente pesimista.

text: It's much better to be optimistic and wrong than pessimistic and right, I think. So I don't know. And I'm an impatient person. I'm a creative person. I'm a messy person. I just like to create and explore and find stuff. So disruptive innovation just seems natural to me.
speaker: Sam Schillace
context: Sam shares his philosophy on optimism versus pessimism in innovation. He argues that there's not much reward for being pessimistic and correct, especially in moments of significant technological change. Sam describes his personal approach to innovation, explaining that his impatient and creative nature naturally leads him toward disruptive innovation work.
text_ko: 제 생각엔 틀려도 낙관적인 게, 맞더라도 비관적인 것보다 훨씬 낫다고 봐요. 글쎄요, 잘 모르겠어요. 저는 성격이 급하고, 창의적이고, 정리정돈은 잘 못하는 편이에요. 그냥 뭔가를 만들고 탐구하고 새로운 걸 찾아내는 걸 좋아해요. 그래서 파괴적 혁신(disruptive innovation)이 저한테는 자연스러워요.
text_zh: 我觉得宁可乐观一点犯错，也比悲观但正确要好得多。所以我也说不准。而且我这个人比较急性子，喜欢创新，做事也比较随性。我就是喜欢去创造、去探索、去发现新东西。所以颠覆式创新(disruptive innovation)对我来说就是很自然的事儿。
text_es: Es mucho mejor ser optimista y equivocarse que ser pesimista y tener razón, ¿no? O sea, no sé. Y soy una persona impaciente. Soy creativa. Soy desordenada. Simplemente me gusta crear y explorar y descubrir cosas. Entonces la innovación disruptiva me parece algo completamente natural.

text: Every new idea looks dumb at first. Unfortunately, the dumb ideas also look dumb at first. It's not a perfect [inaudible]. But the more disruptive they are, the more dumb you're going to feel they are. You always listen for stuff like if they say it's a toy or if it's practical or it's stupid or I don't get it or whatever, those are often... Toy is a good keyword.
speaker: Sam Schillace
context: Lenny discusses first-principles thinking and mentions Steve Jobs' quote about everything being designed by people no smarter than you. Sam responds by explaining that truly innovative ideas often appear foolish initially, though he acknowledges this isn't a perfect filter since bad ideas also look dumb. He suggests listening for specific dismissive language like 'toy' as potential indicators of disruptive innovation.
text_ko: 모든 새로운 아이디어는 처음엔 멍청해 보이는 법이에요. 안타깝게도, 진짜로 멍청한 아이디어들도 처음엔 똑같이 멍청해 보여요. 완벽한 규칙은 아니에요. 하지만 더 '파괴적'(disruptive)일수록 더 멍청하게 느껴질 거예요. 사람들이 '장난감'(toy)이라고 하거나 '실용적이지 않다', '멍청하다', '잘 모르겠다'고 하면 그런 말들을 유심히 들어보세요. 그런 반응들이 중요한 단서인 경우가 많아요. '장난감'(toy)은 좋은 키워드예요.
text_zh: 每个新想法一开始看起来都很蠢。不幸的是，那些真正蠢的想法一开始也看起来很蠢。这个判断标准不是百分百准确的。但是越颠覆性的想法，你越会觉得它们很蠢。你要留意那些评价，比如说"这就是个玩具"或者"不实用"或者"太蠢了"或者"我搞不懂"之类的，这些往往是......其实"玩具"是个很好的关键词。
text_es: Toda idea nueva al principio parece tonta. Por desgracia, las ideas tontas también parecen tontas al principio. No es un sistema perfecto [inaudible]. Pero mientras más disruptivas sean, más tontas te van a parecer. Siempre hay que estar atento cuando dicen cosas como "es un juguetito" o "no es práctico" o "es una estupidez" o "no le veo el punto" o lo que sea, esas suelen ser... "Juguetito" es una palabra clave.

text: And that bifurcation of love it, hate it, is really how you have an idea of whether you have impact in what you're building. If you get more of the bell curve of modern indifference and maybe mild like and mild dislike, that's an's an incremental product. That's not really disrupting anything.
speaker: Sam Schillace
context: Sam explains how to identify whether a product is truly disruptive by observing people's reactions to it. He describes how Google Docs created a strong binary reaction - some people loved it intensely while others wanted it to fail completely. This bifurcation (split) of reactions, rather than moderate responses across a bell curve, indicates genuine disruption and impact.
text_ko: 사람들이 ‘완전 좋아해’ 아니면 ‘완전 싫어해’로 확 갈리는 양상(bifurcation)이 있어야 우리가 만드는 것이 진짜 영향력이 있는지 알 수 있어요. 대부분이 무덤덤하거나 약간 좋아하거나 약간 싫어하는 종형 곡선(bell curve) 분포, 즉 현대적 무관심(modern indifference)이 더 많다면 그건 단지 점진적 제품(incremental product)에 불과하고 실제로 무언가를 뒤흔들거나 파괴하는 것(disrupting)은 아니에요.
text_zh: 这种爱憎分明的两极分化，其实就能让你知道你做的东西到底有没有影响力。如果你得到的反馈都是那种正态分布(bell curve)式的——大家都无所谓，顶多就是有点喜欢或者有点不喜欢，那你做的就是个渐进式产品，根本谈不上什么颠覆。
text_es: Y esa bifurcación de "me encanta" o "lo odio" es realmente como puedes saber si lo que estás construyendo tiene impacto. Si obtienes más de esa curva normal de indiferencia moderna y tal vez un "me gusta" tibio y un "no me gusta" tibio, eso es un producto incremental. Eso realmente no está disrumpiendo nada.

text: I think products almost follow these thermodynamic rules where if you add a little bit of value, your adoption goes slowly and if you add a lot of value, your adoption goes really quickly, right? I think ChatGPT is a great recent example of something that was just added a ton of new value to the world and got this explosive growth.
speaker: Sam Schillace
context: Sam discusses the principle that people are lazy and only adopt products that make their lives significantly easier. He explains that product adoption follows patterns similar to thermodynamic rules - small amounts of added value lead to slow adoption, while substantial value creation results in rapid, explosive growth. He uses ChatGPT as an example of a product that added tremendous value and achieved explosive adoption.
text_ko: 제 생각엔 제품들은 거의 이런 열역학적 규칙(thermodynamic rules)을 따르는 것 같아요. 조금만 가치를 더하면 채택(adoption)이 천천히 늘고, 많은 가치를 한꺼번에 더하면 채택이 훨씬 빠르게 일어나죠. ChatGPT는 최근에 세상에 엄청난 가치를 새로 더해 폭발적인 성장을 이룬 좋은 사례예요.
text_zh: 我觉得产品其实挺像热力学定律的，你要是只增加一点点价值，用户接受起来就比较慢，但如果你能提供巨大价值，那用户接受速度就会非常快，对吧？我觉得ChatGPT就是个很好的例子，它给世界带来了巨大的新价值，所以才会有这种爆炸式增长。
text_es: Creo que los productos siguen casi como las reglas de la termodinámica: si agregas poquito valor, la adopción va lentita, pero si agregas muchísimo valor, la adopción se dispara súper rápido, ¿no? ChatGPT es un ejemplo perfecto de algo reciente que le dio un montón de valor nuevo al mundo y tuvo ese crecimiento explosivo.

text: We tend to undervalue the things we're good at. We tend to think work has to be unpleasant. And so if something is easy and fun, we don't tend to think it's valuable. So I think lots of people gravitate in this direction of like, let's go do unpleasant things and grind our way through the career because that's the way to make it.
speaker: Sam Schillace
context: Lenny asks about Sam's philosophy on career success and taking risks. Sam explains a common misconception people have about work - that it must be difficult and unpleasant to be valuable. He argues that people often undervalue their natural talents and gravitate toward grinding through unpleasant work, thinking this is the path to career success, when actually they should focus on what comes easily and enjoyably to them.
text_ko: 우리는 대체로 잘하는 것의 가치를 과소평가해요. 또 일은 불편하고 고돼야 한다고 생각하는 경향이 있어서, 뭔가 쉽고 재밌으면 가치 없다고 여기는 경우가 많아요. 그래서 많은 사람이 '고생해야 성공한다'고 생각해서 일부러 불편하고 고된 일을 택해 경력을 쌓곤 해요.
text_zh: 我们总是小看自己擅长的东西。我们总觉得工作就得是痛苦的。所以如果某件事做起来轻松又有意思，我们就觉得它不值钱。我觉得很多人都有这种想法，就是得去做那些不爽的事儿，在职场上硬熬，觉得只有这样才能成功。
text_es: Tendemos a subestimar las cosas en las que somos buenos. Tendemos a pensar que el trabajo tiene que ser desagradable. Entonces, si algo es fácil y divertido, no solemos pensar que tiene valor. Creo que mucha gente se va por ese camino de "vamos a hacer cosas que no nos gustan y a trabajar a lo bestia" porque piensan que así es como se triunfa en la carrera profesional.
